list.item: POETA in his Night-cap and Slippers, vnbutton'd and vntrust.

sp.speaker: POETA.
sp.l: Melancholico comes in, and layes down his Lute & departs .BE not farre off.
That nothing is entire!
Nothing all-blest! but still some new desire
Brings a new torture! and this Fate does lie,
An heauie weight on all mortalitie!
It does; thus was not lately my affection
Chain'd to Historia by a strong subiection?
Did I not pule, and pine, intreate, and crie?
Pretend a sicknesse? threaten I would die,
If she not lou'd me? did I not act all
The frantike parts wherewith Loue does inthrall
His Rebell-Subiects? Did I not looke Sad
If shee but Frown'd; and, if shee Smil'd, looke Glad?
I did; and tooke delight to be inchain'd
To her, Hope said at last shee might be gain'd.
Yet see the wheele of change! I now doe scorne
Her teares, and now she thinkes her selfe forlorne.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon my intrusion Sir, Historia Melancholico enters.
Hearing you were hurt lately in a Fray,
Has in her iealousie of loue sent here
Some Physicke, to preuent a greater feare.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: She should haue sent me Poyson, far from her
I count it so; yet let the Messenger
Returne our courteous gratitude. Begon. Exit Melancholico.
Lo, thus vexations neuer come alone;
Well, I woun't loue her; nay, Ile haue her more
Hence-forth; she plagues me worse then before.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon once more, Sir, here comes sent by her,
Medicus, Seruant to administer
The Physicke.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — Why, I prethee know I lacke
No Physicke, there 'tis, thou maist carry't backe.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: The Gods forbid, Sir, this is Poyson. Sanguis lookes on the poyson.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — How!

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: 'Tis Poyson, Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — Why? it was sent but now
From my Loue-sicke Historia.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.l: — So 't may be:
They'ue chang'd my Masters Physicke.

lg.l: The Treacherie of women! well, conceale
The fact as yet; iust time shall all reueale.
O Women, Witches, Monsters, Furies Deuils,
The impure extract of a World of euils;
Of the Gods Wisdome; and th' Anomalie
From all that's good; I'l curse you all below
The Center, and, if I could, then further throw
Your cursed heads; and if any should gaine
A place in Heau'n, Ile time 'em downe againe
To a worse ruine; yet me thinkes I heare
How Astronomia whispers in mine eare,
And begs a Pardon for them; well; to thee
I'l yeeld, thou stand'st aboue mortalitie.
Aspire, my gentle Muse, inflame my brest;
Then thus my gracefull loue shall be exprest.
Her Brow is like a braue Heroicke line,
That does a sacred Maiestie inshrine.
Her Nose Phaleuciake-like in comely sort
Ends in a Trochie, or a long and short.
Her Mouth is like a prettie Dimeter;
Her Eie-browes like a little-longer Trimeter.
Her Chinne is an Adonicke; and her Tongue—
Her Eies, I may compare them vnto two
Quick-turning Dactyles, for their nimble View.
Her Necke Asclepiad-like turnes round about
Behind, before a little bone stands out.
Her Ribs like Staues of Sapphickes doe descend
Thither, which but to name were to offend.
Her Armes like two Iambickes rais'd on hie,
Doe with her Brow beare equall Maiestie.
Her Legs like two strait Spondies, keep a pace
Slow as two Scazons, but with stately grace.
Thankes to my Muse; yet why doe I admire
Her thus, whom I enioy but by desire?
For more I neuer shall; this is my waight
Of griefe, and this my preordained Fate.
He takes vp his Lute .Come, come, thou part of Heau'n, companion
Of all my woes and loues, thou that alone
Dost in the mid'st of sorrowes yeeld reliefe,
And though not take away, make lesse my griefe.
lg.stage: He playes on his Lute, then leaues off, and speakes againe.
lg.l: My dearest Lute, Apoollo's best inuention
Wherewith he does compose the wilde dissention
Of our vntun'd desires, which would confound
Vs quite, but that they breake forth with a sound!
Sighes from our brests are like sounds from thy wombe,
Borne dead, and buri'd in an aërie Tombe.
Sigh then to Cupid, tell him he's too blame
Not raising in my loue a mutuall flame.

div.stage: He playes on his Lute, and leauing off, cals to his man

sp.speaker: MELANCHOLICO.
sp.p: Ho, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: — Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — Begon.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Did you not call me Sir?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — Sirrah, begon.
sp.stage: He playes a little on his Lute, and then cals MELANCHOLICO againe.
sp.p: Ho, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: — Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Dance, I say, Dance.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: — I can't.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — Sirrah, dance that which I play.
sp.stage: He playes the Antique on his Lute, and MELANCHOLICO dances, then abruptly leauing off, he speakes to him.
sp.l: Begon: MELANCHOLICO continues dancing. Sirrah, begon.
sp.stage: Hee playes againe on his Lute, and suddenly leauing off, throwes it away.
sp.l: — Away, away,
Charmer, Inchanter, tis a truth to say,
Our bodies cast their shapes into the Ayre,
And can appeare when they are gon; so rare
Philosophers haue held, and so I hold:
Pardon, great Astronomia, I was bold,
Too-bold, I doe confesse, but my dimme sight
Could not before behold thee though so bright.
But now mine eyes are cleer'd; on my bow'd knee,
I aske a Pardon of thy Maiestie.
Pardon thy Poet, and vouchsafe this grace, He faines Astronomia to be present, fals on his knees, imbraces and kisses the ayre: then rises.
That thy rich beauties he may thus imbrace.
And now, deare Loue, adde hereunto one kisse,
And then thou shalt in heau'n my soule with blisse.
Maro, thy Riddle's solu'd: I thus vntye
The knot, which thou didst knit, mens wits to try.
Dic quibus in terris (& eris mihi magnus APOLLO)
Tres pateat Coeli spatium (non amplius) vlnas?
Maro, 'tis here; here's Astronomia;
Here's Heau'n clos'd in those narrow limits; nay,
Here's Deitie, the obiect of all loues,
Enough to make a thousand Heau'ns of Ioues.
See, He thinkes he sees her ascending into Heauen .see, how she ascends! mount, mount, great Queene
Of Heau'n, and in full lustre be thou seene
Mortalities amazement; see, she's gone
To mount yet higher to a stately Throne,
Plac'd on the Azure pauement of the Starres,
Guarded by Dayes, Monthes, Houres, then sees the warres
Of Pygmie-mortals—. Enter MELANCHOLICO.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: — Sir, here's Ethicus
Is come, and sayes hee'd speake with you.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — With vs?
Admit him in. Exit Melancholico. Enter ETHICVS.

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — Hay! scarce drest yet! how so?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: What? comes your froward age to chide vs?

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — No.
But to inuite you to a Feast, my selfe your friend,
Desirous of your peace, to set an end
To your contentions with Grammaticus
And Logicus, to night doe purpose thus
To make you friends.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — Nay, no buts: Be there.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — Why thankes. Welcome shall be your cheere.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: Well then, Ile in and dresse me, and so come,
Yet better twere purchance you had my roome. Exit Poeta.

sp.p: But Sir, can it be lawfull to deale with spirits?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Whilst you are onely a Geometrician, it is lawfull
for you to deale only with bodies: but if you will vndertake Our Superiour facultie, 'tis not onely lawfull, but most honourable; why Sir, 'tis one of the greatest gifts of the Gods to haue command ouer Spirits; but for the approbation of it, you may only looke backe vnto the antiquitie thereof, which is drawne from more then eight hundred yeeres before the Siege of Troy, in the time of Agonaces, and of the renowned Zoroaster a King of the Bactrians, who described the high Mysterie of this Diuine Science in an hundred thousand verses; after these there flourished Iobeth, Toluscol, Zamolxis, whose admired fame was afterwards emulated by Almadal, Alchindus, and Hipocus Arabians: Apuscorus, Zaratus, and Cobares, Medians: Marmaridius, a Babylonian: Zarmocenidas, an Assyrian, Abbaris, an Hyperborean, Thesphetion, an Aethiopian, Arnuphis, an Aegyptian, Theurgus, a Chaldean: with these I may recite Cambyses, Zamares, Charondas, Damogorgon, Gobrias, Arbatel, Apollonius, Gog, Hostanes, Atyr, Choastes—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Good Sir, doe not coniure.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: No Sir, these are nothing but the names of the Sacred Professours of this Diuine Science.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: I but it may be Sir, they had coniuring names.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Alas, Sir! 'tis not so easie a matter to worke effectually in our Sacred Science, as most men thinke it is, and as I will most manifestly declare vnto you; for this is a rule, you must be first an Absolute Astrologian; vpon which fundamentall Supposition I thus proceed: before you can obtaine the knowledge of Astrologie, you must be a most Grounded Philosopher, a sound Physician, and an exquisite Mathematician; by the helpes of which Sciences you shall know the courses of the Starres; the number of the Orbes; your Poles; the Circles; the Verticall and Pedall points; the Azimuth, or Verticall Circle; the Almucantarath or Circles of Altitude; the Concentricitie and Excentricitie of the Orbes; the Ascendent, and Descendent Knots, or Syndesmes, that Cut the Ecliptike; your Orbes Aequant, Epicyclicall, and Deferent of the Apogeum, and Perigeum, or of the Highest and Lowest Absis; the Planetarie Aspects, or Configurations, either Right
as Coniunction and Opposition, or Collaterall as Sextile, Quadrate, and Trine; the Direct motion of the Planets, their Retrogradation & Station; then Sir, your Astrologie is either Canonicall for the Influence of the Starres, or Thematicall for the Erection of a Scheme of the Heauens, wherein is to bee knowne the Order of the Domicils, and the Inscription. Then there is your Iudiciarie, which is either Genethliacall, or Catholike instructing in predictions, either Idiomaticall or Symptomaticall; the eight and twentie Mansions of the Moone; the Symbolization of Occult qualities in Herbs, with the Planets; Signacles, Pentacles, Planetarie Suffumigations, Vnctions, Pailters, Rings, Alligations, Suspensions; the twelue Scales of the Numbers; the Duodenarie Scale, either Cabalisticall or Orphicall; the Characters, Seales, and Bands of Spirits—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: You'l giue me all this in writing Sir; woun't you?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Yes Sir, yes. Then are there diuers kinds of your Magicke, as Necromancie, Anthropomancie, Gastromancie, Cheiromancie, Coscinomancy,—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: I pray, doe you your selfe know how many there are in all?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Sir, One and twentie. Ile begin them ouer againe, if you will. Necromancie, Anthropomancie—

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir hold, we haue enough alreadie: But I perceiue you Magicians haue admirable memories to get hard words by heart; I maruaile you doe not turne Dictionarie-makers: Why? I warrant there's no hard word but you can tell the meaning on't: you'd put all their noses out of ioynt quite.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
I, and put them out of their wits, if wee list: But then, Sir, to know the Spirit of Euerie Day, and Houre; his Name, Power, and Legions vnder him, his Forme of appearing, whether like a Dragon, or an Horse, or a Wolfe, or a flame of fire; the Region whence he comes; the Gift hee bestowes, whether Learning, Riches, Beautie; his Name, his Characters: these, these, are the wonders, the amazements of our Spirituall Science; Spirituall I may iustly call in, since euerie Art receiues an Excellencie from its Obiect; and yet (alas!)
I confesse, I am but young in it yet, and haue scarce serued a 'prentice-ship in it, if it may bee call'd a seruitude, wherein there is such Freenesse, and Euagation of spirit in such exquisite knowledge; nay, Dominion ouer Spirits.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Young say you? marry, I thinke, you are absolutely grounded in it, that can know all these Mysteries; ah, were it the will of the gods, I had but halfe of this skill, I'de giue all that I haue, and get more as I could; but can you doe all these Wonders?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Farre stranger, farre stranger; most amazing transformations; why, there was Apuleius so skilfull in this Arte, that he turn'd himselfe into an Asse, and Lucian was turn'd into an Asse, before he studi'd it.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: O strange! but can a Spirit giue Learning?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Oh, there was Hermolaus Barbarus, when he studied Philosophie, and lesse vnderstood any place, hee would call vp a Spirit to instruct him; so the famous Cardans father carryed one alwaies in a Ring on his finger; and Agrippa had his Dogge with a Characteriz'd Collar.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: But can you by your Art, tell mee whether or no I shall haue Astronomia?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Why, I can doe it by Coscinomancie.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: By the turning of a Siue.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: But I haue heard, that's onely for things stolne.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis more generall, and that you shall see; stay here, Ile but step forth. Exit Magus.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Well, this is the man whom the Heauens haue ordain'd to make me happie; O Venus, be fauourable vnto me, and Ile build thee a fayrer Temple then euer the Ephesians directed to Diana. MAGVS enters.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Come Sir, here are Sheeres and a Siue; I must fasten the Sheeres? now doe as I bid you; Hold vp the side of the Sheeres with your finger. (he puts the wrong finger )Nay, come, your middle-finger: So; now must I say a mysticall forme of powerfull words, and then name those that wee suspect
shall haue her; and amongst them name you also; and at whose name the Siue turnes, he shall haue her.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: If it do's not turne at mine, I shall die: 'pray make it turne at mine.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Nay, then it must goe for nothing, for it must turne of its owne accord. Be silent now. Dies mies, Ieschet, bene doefet, Dowima, Enitemaus. Who shall haue Astronomia? Shall Poeta? (It stands still. )Who shall haue Astronomia? Shall Logicus?

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Hee's not in loue with her, Sir; 'pray doe not you put in him too.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: O vile! peace; now must I begin againe. Diet mies, Ieschet, Bene doefet, Dowima, Enitemaus. Who shall haue Astronomia? Shall Poeta? (It stands still. )Who shall haue Astronomia? Shall Logicus? (It stands still. )Who shall haue Astronomia? Shall Geographus? (It moues a little. )Who shall haue Astronomia? Shall Geometres? (It turnes round. )Shall he obtaine her by Coniuration? (It stands still. )Shall hee obtaine her by Medicine? (It moues a little. )Shall hee obtaine her by Fascination? (It turnes round.)

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Georaetres falls downe on his knees, and imbraces Magus his knees .Magus, what's mine is yours, goods, life, soule, and all: Venus, thy temple shall be a mile in length; thy Image in't shall be greater then the Colossus at Rhodes, it shall bee all white Marble: The temple at Millaine shall looke like pale-fac'd tallow to it; it shall haue as many pillars, as there are houres in the yeere, and as many windowes as there are minutes; and the Spire shall be higher then Tenariffa, or the Tower of Babylon by eight score Measured furlongs at the least. Magus, I haue enough, I haue enough.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Nay but, Sir, you must Measure your ioy; diuers haue died with ouer-much reioycing, and so may you; and then you'd both breake your vow to the Goddesse, and lose your Loue besides.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: You say true.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Besides, you must vse a meanes you see, Fascination; which you shall vse at the Banquet, which (you know) we are inuited vnto.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p:
Nay, let mee alone for looking on her; Ile looke
thorow her, and thorow her; and make her as Perspectiue, as I am Solid.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Besides, there was a little moouing, you saw, at the name of Geographus: to signifie hee will bee faire for her too. And againe, there was a little moouing at the word Medicine, and therefore that must bee vs'd too: but for that take you no care.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Well, you learned men put so many doubts— but I care not, I shall haue her in the end: come, I'ue enough, now let's goe.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Measure your ioy, I say.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Thou'rt mine, thou'rt mine, Astronomia, I'me in Heau'n already; Geographus may goe trauaile againe, and Poeta, in stead of Baies, may goe weare a Willow-garland.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Come, let's in. Exeunt Geometres & Magus.
MArry, and I bee thus troubled with you when you woo me, and seeke to please; what should I expect and wee were married once?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nay, dearest Logicus, let not the excellencie of your reason bee so seuere, but that it may admit a gracious apprehension of a smiling loue; let not the exactnes of your wisedome be so regulated, but that it may expresse a courteous acceptance of a Louers admiration; let not—

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Nay, and you once fall to Set speeches, I am gone; I perceiue you are not for common talke; I wonder, now I thinke on't, in what Praedicament a womans tongue is; let's see: yet, what if I make it a Transcendent? and yet it can't be so, for 'tis neither vnum, nor verum, nor honum: 'faith, and't bee in any Praedicament, it shall bee in Quantitate Continua, and that's opposite to Discreta; or rather, since 'tis so irregular, and therefore can hardly bee admitted into any Order, I will count it that Monster in Nature, and Contradiction of Philosophie, Infinitum in acta.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Why lo, now your selfe has made a set speech; and
thus whilst you Reprehend, you Offend: whilst you Direct, you Neglect: whilst you Reforme, you Deforme: whilst you—

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Hey day! this is tick-tack: Here's another shorter tricke: well, I perceiue there's no other course— which is your way?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Which is your way?

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Doe you speake first.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nay, doe you speake first, you are the better Man.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Why, mine lies this way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why so does mine; weele goe together.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: I, But I must go this way to doe a little businesse first.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why so must I.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: But I must walke here alone a little to thinke on't first.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I must walke here alone a little first.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Why, then fare you well; I can thinke on my busines by the way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I can very well thinke on my businesse by the way.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: Why, you woun't follow me? I am going to a Feast.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I am going to a Feast.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: I am going to Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I am going to Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Log.
sp.p: O you gods! which of you will come to deliuer me? Well, if wee must together, and if you will sticke so close vnto me; yet, good Mistres Tongue, do not cleaue to the roofe of my Mouth.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: No, no; your lippe is all that I desire.

div.head: ACTVS III. SCENA IIII.
div.stage: MVSICA at one doore: GEOGRAPHVS and PHANTASTES at another.

sp.p: TAra, ding de ding, ding de ding, lan, tan, dan, dido.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: How now my nimble Crotchet? who was the first Fiddle-maker?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thats's a question, Sir.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Why, for that reason I propos'd it.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, for that reason you might haue propos'd many more.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I, but Answere.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I, but I must know first; 'tis a great controuersie.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: What then was the first kinde of Instrument?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, that's as hard.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Why, I can tell.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: An Harpe.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I but you're deceiu'd, I rather thinke 'twas a Bagge-pipe.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: A Bag-pipe? why prethee?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why? marry, first vnderstand this reason, and then Ile shew you: You know euery Art both drawes it's imitation from Nature, and labours to perfect it, which it does by finding comforts to preserue it: Musicke then at the first was found out as an antidote against griefe: and by this meanes, when men were grieued, they cried Oh, and there was one Note: then Hey-ho, there were two Notes more. So, when they laught, they obseru'd three more by Ha, ha, ho. These being first ioyn'd together, and afterwards variously intermixt, were the first harmonie in voice; which being repeated vnto grieued mindes, were as it were a prettie deluding of their sorrowes; and these by obseruation were afterwards reduc'd to instrument—

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I conceit it, Musica.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thus, men perceiuing that these notes were conceiu'd in the bellie, and afterwards, (as it were) form'd in the passage of the throat, sowed Leather in the forme of a Bellie, or bagge; and wth a Reed made a long Necke vnto it, and a Winde-pipe; which when they blew full of winde, and perceiu'd it gaue no sound, they cut many holes in the reed to let it out, and then alternately stopping the holes, they found an admirable varietie of harmony; and as the holes serue for distinction of notes in a Winde-instrument, so doe your frets on a String'd-instrument.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
Indeede I thinke this a truth; for as the voice was before the Instrument, so the Winde-instrument before the
string'd. But then how came your Trumpet vp?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, on this manner: When Triton came to helpe the gods in the Warres of the Gyants, he wanted a weapon, and finding the shell of a Fish, he did blow in't, which yeelded a most hideous noise: the Gyants thinking it had beene some terrible beast, fled away affrighted, and since by a perfecting imitation, men haue alter'd both the matter, and the forme of that Instrument.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Nay, I do beleeue there is a great vertue in Musicke.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: O Sir, 'tis your onely medicine of the minde.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Indeed I thinke so, and that's the reason, 'tis likely, why Apollo is the god both of Musicke and Physicke: and now I remember it, in one place where we came, in our trauailes, there were no Physicions, but all their sicke folks were cur'd by Musicke; where was it, Phantastes? I haue quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Why 'twas in Creet Sir, where Iupiter was nurs'd, and the Musicke was made with those Kettle-drums, which they sounded to drowne the crying of Iupiter, when he was in his swathe-bands: in reward of which loue, hee procur'd of Apollo, in the fauour of the Cretians, that at the sound of those Kettle-drummes all sicke folkes, whose time of death was not come, should without any languishing sicknes immediately recouer; and therefore the order is, when any one is sicke, they carry him presently in a Litter to the Temple where these Drums are kept; and if hee does not straight-wayes recouer, they carry him home againe, as a man that must dye, and so prouide for his funerall.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Where is this Sir? in Creet?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Yes, in Creet.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I, but I haue heard, the Cretians are mightie liars.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Vpon the Faith of a Trauellour, the Honestie of a Courtier, and the Word of a Gentleman, 'tis a most confirm'd truth.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Indeed these three are much about one valew.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Well, Musica, I could talke with thee all day—

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: I, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
But I cannot stay now; I'me afraid they stay for me
at the banquet. Is thy Mistris there?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Yes, I thinke, by this time.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Well, farewell till anon: you'll meet vs at supper? woun't you?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'me going for Musike. Exit Geogra.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Come, my prettie Pigeon, let's bill a little; is't possible, Phantastes and Musica should meet, and part without a kisse?— now farewell. Exit Phantastes.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Ah: these Courtiers are lycourish-lip'd: but I must goe fetch the Musike, To ra ding de ding, ding de ding, lan, tan dan dido. Exit Musica.

div.head: ACTVS III. SCENA V.
ETHICVS, GEOMETRES, LOGICVS, POETA, GRAMMATICVS, MAGVS, ASTRONOMIA, ARITHMETICA, RHETORICA, ASTROLOGIA, CHOLER.

sp.p: WElcome, welcome, all of you; i'good faith, I'm e'en young againe, to see such a jolly company of my friends together: but, passion o' me! why, Oeconoma?

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: I, I, presently, presently, Shee speakes from within .wee'r making all haste wee can.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Ah, there's a good huswife, neither meat oth' table, nor cloth laid, nor any thing in a readinesse. Good friends pardon vs, wee are somewhat vnmannerly to make you stay thus; wee'll talke till supper is seru'd in; but where's Geographus? Enter GEOGRAPHVS and PHANTASTES .Oh here is; welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Thanks, They all salute him, & he them mutually, especially the Ladies .courteous Ethicus— saue you gallants— faire Ladies—

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Phantastes, and Choler, [Enter MVSICA ]and thou Musica, now thou art come, be a little forward to make a supply for our backwardnesse, and step in to my wife to help out supper quickly: (Exeunt Phantast. Choler, & Musica )why 'tis well, 'tis well, now 'tis as it should be, all friends, all friends: but where's Historia?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Historia? why, aske Poeta.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Mee?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: I, you; they say shee's sicke of loue.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Poeta, where's your man Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Faith, when I was comming hither, hee was in a dump, and therefore I thinking him not fit to come to a banquet, left him behind me; and indeed that's his fault, hee will not commonly be merry in company.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Logicus, where's your man Phlegmatico?

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p: Faith, as I was comming, my Slauerer was at his Tobacco, but, I thinke, I made him smoke for his labour, and so would not let him come, for hee would nothing but haue spawl'd in your roome, Phantastes, Choler, Musica, bring in Supper. and haue turn'd your stomakes.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, remember this Phantastes.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: That you carry in the march-pane and not I, but Ile—

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: What? amn't I the better man?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Would supper were done: I'd bumme you.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he's angrie that I brought in the march-pane.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Phantastes, Choler, Musica, go out againe Come, be mannerly.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Why, sirrah, Choler, will you still be quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: You should let him be my man a little; faith I should be as froward as he; we two should haue a bickering once a day. (Choler to Phantast. as they come in with more seruice.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: I would supper were done once for your sake.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Why, sirrah, are you still grumbling?

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Come, friends, you are all welcome, we haue made you stay here too-long for a little sorry cheere; come husband will you place the guests?

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Sit downe, you know your places; sit downe (they all sit downe )wife, bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: You are all heartily welcome, heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Why, Musica, where are the Musicians?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Come on, play, feed you our eares, whilst we seed our bellyes. The musike playes; Geographus drinks to Astronomia; shee to Geometria; hee to Arithmetica shee to Astrologia; shee drinks to Astronomia, then priuily casts in a powder: which being done, Phantastes sings.

lg.l: If you fell not at ods,
And did not your selues annoy.
But when pride does once tickle,
And bring vs in tune againe.
And turne with each strong wind.
Where Musicke and Loue do meet!
To make his pipe sound more sweet:
Where the Wine in the boules,
And trippe it in comely sort.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Here, Logicus, you shall drinke to Poeta,

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p: I accept your Proposition, Sir; Poeta, to set a Conclusion to our former dissentions, and to make a plaine Demonstration of reconcilement, I drinke to you. He drinkes.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: With the most ingenuous freedome of a Poet, I accept it: Grammaticus, that our contention ending in loue, may make a Tragike-Comedie, I drinke to you. He drinkes.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: I protest to you, Sir, I doe put all former wrongs in the praeter-plu-perfect Tence, and am glad of this happy Coniunction, and that we are all of vs in such a merry Mood: but by the way, my Masters, these Noune-Adiectiues of the Foeminine gender, sit all this while vn-drunke to: Astronomia. He offers to drinke to Astronomia.—

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Intruth, Grammaticus, I am not in Case to pledge you: I pledg'd Astrologia euen now, and I am not since halfe well.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Arithmetica—

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: If you Count again, you shal find that I drunk last.
Rhetorica— here's to moysten your eloquent tongue.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: An eloquent tongue is neuer drie, Astrologia will pledge you for me.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Astrologia—

sp.speaker: Astrol.
sp.p: In troth I haue been drinking my Belly full of Nectar; but iust now, my thoughts were vpon the present Coniunction of Mars and Venus.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Why how now, Grammaticus! who doe you drinke to? faith thou art now a Noune Substantiue indeed, for thou standst alone by thy selfe, without being ioyn'd to any of these Adiectiues.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Nay, doe not you iest.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: What? dost thou make a Iester of me?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, I Coniure you both; by our present meeting, that you goe not out of the Circle of harmelesse mirth.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Me thinks I see a Direct line passe from the Eye of Geometres to Astronomia's.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, will you, Poeta? you make Astronomia blush.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Some Aqua vitae, I say, for Geometres.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Why, Poeta?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Why, hee's a dying I thinke, his eyes are fixt in's head alreadie.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: It may be, Poeta, you measure Geometres his lookes by your owne.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Me thinks I see a Direct line passe from the Eye of Geometres to Astronomia's.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: I'm eu'n stifled, I doe not vse to be in such a close Roome, I loue the Open Aire.

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Alas! Astronomia's extreme ill. Exeunt Astronomia & Oeconoma.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Friends, you are all heartily welcome, rest you here I pray, and weele in with her. Exit Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Astrologia, follow her, and see you be neuer from her all the while shee's sicke.

sp.speaker: Astrol.
sp.p: I saw this disastrous chance in the starres, for as Mars and Venus were sporting, they were beheld by the rest of the enuious gods. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Ile in too, to sit and Talke with her, whiles shee's
sicke. Exit Rhetorica.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ile in too, that I may—

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Be made sit downe againe.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Alas, my Mistris!

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Shee did not looke well.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Astronomia sicke? then all the Heauen's awry, and my Musike's quite out of tune. Exit Musica.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: 'Twas, I feare me, a fit of an Ague.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Astronomia in a fit of an Ague? I neuer vnderstood the Motus trepidationis of the Heauen before.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Musicians, depart the roome. The Musicians go out.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: By Ioue I came to be merry, and I will be merry. Here's an health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Here's a health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Here's a health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Sir, you wrong vs all, not to take off your full measure.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, they that drinke with Measure, drinke without Measure.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: I, indeed, for they that Number their cups, commonly Multiply their cups.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: He loues not Astronomia, that does not pledge her a whole one.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Well, because 'tis to her, Ile doo't, He drinks.

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p: I can't drinke.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: You woun't, I know, require it of me.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Well, and you woun't, here's to you that will: A second health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: A second health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: A second health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: By Ioue I must be merry, and I will be merry; can you sing?

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Beginne, wee'll follow.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Beginne, wee'll follow.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Haue at you then.
sp.l: FIll up my boule to the brim-a,
That my lips in wine may swim-a;
That my Muse may slow
And the world may it know:
Fill vp my boule to the brimme-a

sp.speaker: Poeta. Geog. Geom.
sp.l: That my Muse may slow
And the world may it know:
Fill vp my bowle to the brimme-a.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.l: Hee's a puny cannot swagger,
Carouse and yet neuer stagger,
But be soberly drunke
And closely haue his punke:
Hee's a puny cannot swagger.

sp.speaker: Geog. Poeta. Geom.
sp.l: But he soberly drunke
And closely haue his punke:
Hee's a puny cannot swagger.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.l: O my Iacobs staffe is broken,
And thats a disast'rous token,
My Compasses did slide,
My Ruler slipt aside:
O my Iacobs staffe is broken.

sp.speaker: Geom. Geog. Poeta.
sp.l: My Compasses did slide
My Ruler slipt aside
O my Iacobs-staffe is broken.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: Come kisse, come kisse, my Corinna,
And still that sport wee'l beginn-a,
That our soules so may meet
In our lippes, while they greet:
Come kisse, come kisse, my Corinna.

sp.speaker: Poeta. Geog. Geom.
sp.l: That our soules so may meet
In our lippes, while they greet:
Come kisse, come kisse, my Corinna.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Here's a health to Astronomia.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Here's a health to Astronomia.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Here's a health to Astronomia. Prethee Poeta doe thou sing a Catch alone, and wee'l sing the Close with thee.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: A match, hay boyes.

lg.l: As it is tost on by-a
Till at last they fall to blowes,

sp.speaker: Poeta. Geog. Geom.
sp.l: — Growes,
Flowes,
Till at last the fall to blowes,
And make their noddles cry-a.
The browne bowle,
The merry browne bowle,
As it goes round about-a.
Fill
Still
Let the world say what it will
And drinke your drinke all out-a.

sp.speaker: Poeta. Geog. Geom.
sp.l: — Fill
Still
Let the world say what it will
And drinke your drinke all out-a.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: The deepe Canne
The merry deepe Canne
As thou dost freely quaffe a.
Sing.
Fling.
Be as merry as a King
And Sound a lusty laugh a.

sp.speaker: Poeta. Geog. Geom.
sp.l: Sing.
Fling.
Be as merry as a King
And sound a lusty laugh a.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Here's a health to Astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Faith, I can drinke no more, Poeta.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: How? not pledge me? Choler, fil the bowle againe; by Ioue, not pledge me? pledge me, pledge me, Geographus: for by Ioue—

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: I will drinke with thee, and I will sing with thee, and I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, 'pray let's haue no fighting.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: By Ioue. I will drinke with thee, I will sing with thee, and I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: By Ioue you're almost foxt.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: By Ioue (He drinks )you lowsie-shirted rogue, you sit aboue mee? did not you begge entertaynment of me tother day?

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Sleepe, sleepe, Poeta. Exit Geographus.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: A rope of a drunken foole; I'ue lost my supper by this: I must follow my Master. Exit Phant.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Ten-toes, I know you're a good footman; Come, Geometres, I hope you'll sit squarely to it still.

sp.speaker: Geom.
sp.p: Nay, if I cannot Rule others, I will Rule my selfe. Exit Geometres.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: And if Geometres depart, Arithmetica will be none of the Number. Exit Arith.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Farewell, Hostesse; we shall be sure to haue no reckoning now Arithmetica's gone: and yet Ile pay you somewhat, Clinch-fist. (Hee beates Logicus, and ouer-turnes the Table; then fals on Grammaticus, and Choler. )Hay tables! Hay!

sp.speaker: Logic.
sp.p:
Well, you drunken rogue, Ile haue an Opposition
for you before Polites, that you shall not be able to Answere to. Exit Logicus.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Farewell block-head: now pae-da-gog, pa-da-gog: I must say my Part to you too.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: I, but, I can't stay to Heare you, now.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Choler, wil not you fight for your Master, valiantly?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: No, I thanke you, Sir, your moysture does allay my heat. Exit Choler.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Are you all gone? then, Apparent rari nantes in gurgite vasto. I am King, I am King: by Tantalus I am as drie as an Horse. He fals downe and sleepes. Magus charmes him .O, some drinke, some drinke.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Alte dormi, Irioni, Chiriori, Essera, Chuder, Fere; Pax, Caspor, Prax, Melchior, Max, Balthasar, Ymax, Adimax, Galbes, Galbat, Galdes, Galdat, Hax, pax, max, alte dormi. Poeta snores: Magus waues his rod ouer him, and runnes round about him. Oh, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho; O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. Dragons fly swiftly, Dragons fly swiftly.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Dancing about Poeta. O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.l: They goe leisurely about him, saying this charme .YEe gods that dwell
In darkest cell
Of lowest Hell,

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.l: Vouchsafe this grace
A little space
To guard this place.

sp.speaker: Cheito.
sp.l: Let now a deepe
And moystning sleepe
His watch here keepe.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.l: We would obtaine
This, for this swaine,
Whom wine doth chaine.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.l: That so since day
Is fled, we may
Make him our pray.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, Dauncing about him .ho, ho, ho, hoy—

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. In his sleepe.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: What a Rogue's this? hee laughes at vs in his Dreame.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho. O ho, ho, ho, ho, ho: In his sleepe .Some drinke, Tantalus, some drinke, some drinke; or I will—

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: What will he doe?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the— by the—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: He's about to sweare sure by somewhat.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great— By the great—

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: He will sweare by the Great.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great— By the great—

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: 'Tis so great 'twoun't come out.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great Hogs-head at Heidelburge, Logicus is a Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: Well said i'faith, I perceiue there is some remembrance of ones friends in Wine.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Corinna, will you kisse? will you kisse cockle-kisse? close, close, you Whore.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Oh, here's a braue Dreamer!

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I will make this Verse like a Nut-hooke-like a Nut-hooke-and then pull downe— pull downe the Moone with it. He begins to rise.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: Sure, Magus, you han't charm'd him well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let me alone; I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Come kisse, my Pigeon, come kisse, my pretty Corinna, Nibble a little, my Loue; nibble againe, and againe.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Hay day! he's at's Hexameter and Pentameter Verses in our tongue: 'faith I thinke in some such humour this kind of Verses was first made amongst vs.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: My purse is richer than th' Mines rich India brings forth.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: You shall not neede to make a short Verse to that Sir: weele be very short with you. He is about to picke his pocket.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Take off your whole one, or take a sowse o' the chops. Poeta strikes Cheiromantes

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Beshrow his drunken fingers; Magus you ha' not charm'd him well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p:
Altè dormi, pax, prax, max; aliè dormi, Galbos, Galbat:
Galdes, Galdat: pax, prax, max, alte dormi. Poeta fals downe againe.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: See what's in his pocket. Cheiromantes takes out a purse and lookes in it.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: A murren on't, here's nothing but a Purse with a paper in't.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Let's see it, why, whats here? Verses! Hee takes the paper and reads it.
Translated by mee vpon occasion of Ethicus his inuiting mee to Supper.

quote.l: The fruitfull Earth does drinke the raine;
Trees drinkes the fruitfull Earth againe.
The Sea does drinke the liquid Ayre;
By the Sunnes beames the Sea-waues are
Drunke vp; which is no sooner done,
But straight the Moone drinkes vp the Sunne.
Why then, companions, doe you thinke
I may not with like freedome drinke?

sp.p: This had beene lost, if I had not giu'n the Rogue his Anacreon againe. Is this the rich Purse? Come, 'ifaith wee'll e'en serue for a Voyder, and carrie him away, whiles hee is drunk, rid the roome of him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Roome for a Poet, Roome for a Poet, Roome for a Poet. Exeunt Omnes, carrying away Poeta on their shoulders.
ANd haue you beene in Italie too?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: In the most parts of the World, Sir.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: You haue dispos'd your obseruations by heads! haue you not?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: They are yet Sir but a miscellany, but I am now in reducing of them.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: And what may the summe of them be?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Sir, they are principally drawne from the People, and Country: discoursing vpon the policie, and naturall disposition of the first; as on the situation, and fertilitie of the second.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Hum, the method is sufficiently approoueable: but I like that very well that you place Policy first; and would wish you to prosecute that fully, with the most subtle examinations of your purest iudgement: 'twill be worth your trauaile: and 'tis a maine fault of your common Geographers, that now-a-dayes doe rather garnish the margine of a Map, then materially describe it; and onely draw a companie of lines through it; as if they had rid ouer the Countrie to take notice onely of the high-wayes; which yet a Carriers Horse knowes better then they; neglecting in the meane time more solid obseruations; whilest their fancies (I will not say iudgements) are weakly satisfied with these fruitlesse superficialities; not vnlike your sedentary Students, who for the attaining of a little glorie with some few lesse iudicious of their owne Sect, stirred vp with a contemplatiue ambition, earnestly prosecute those studies, which themselues shall neuer reduce vnto practice, in the actions of their life.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Sir, the obseruation of gouernment was my first and principall intendment, especially in some secrets of state, as yet (to my knowledge) not obseru'd, at least not reueal'd by any.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: As what?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I will shew vnto you.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: But how could you come vnto the knowledge of them?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: You shall vnderstand that too. The secret is concerning the happie detection of such, as from enemy-states, are vsually sent to the subuersion of a Land; my meanes of attayning to the knowledge of this Mysterie, was my acquaintance with a Gentleman in Italie, who hauing beene one of the most practis'd Intelligencers in Europe, vpon the death of his Lord, who imploy'd him, fell into great wants; when, out of the fulnesse of a grieued mind, and the rather to excite in me a compassion of his griefes, vnfolded vnto mee the whole secret.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
The Italian Lord, that imploy'd this Gentleman, furnished him alwayes with money, that hee might cast himselfe
into what shape he would, then sent him to the enemies Land, where liuing, (either concealing his owne Countrey, or professing a dislike of it) and insinuating himselfe into the acquaintance of men next to the best, would, commonly by entertaining their humours, and giuing occasion of such discourse at any meeting, with much Art and ease, allure euery man, to discouer (euen for glory, to show who could show most) all intended and secret imployments into forraine Lands; by this meanes hee would learne the whole designe, agent, time, and whatsoeuer other necessarie circumstance; then the person to be imploy'd, being commonly of estate not beyond himselfe, hee would vpon some sought (though but slight) occasion, grow so farre acquainted with him, as to intreat the courtesie of Nations of him, to carry a Letter from him to that Countrey; which being with all courtesie granted, he would, against the time of his departure, prouide a Letter fairely written, containing nothing but some complement, or lighter businesse to his friend—

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Who? to his Lord?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: No, Sir, but to another agent, whom his Lord imploy'd at home, as this Gentleman abroad.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Withall giuing his friend in charge, vpon their loue, to giue all courteous entertainment to the bearer thereof; as, to prouide him a fit lodging, with all other complements of friendship: then reading this Letter to the Gentleman, to free him from all suspicion of false dealing, would seale it in his presence, and deliuer it to him—

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: What deuice was there in this?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: This Letter, Sir, being written by the Art of Steganography, contained the whole intendement of this imployd Messenger. That Art (as Trithemius has at large discouer'd, or rather taught it) proceeds vpon many deuices, as the putting together euery first letter of a word, or euery last, or euery second, according to the compact before lay'd betweene these two friends. Vpon the receit of which, proceeded first a most courteous entertayning, and then vpon the maturitie of his intendements, an artificiall detection of al his designes.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: All this beares a iust probabilitie of truth. Well, Geographus, we shall take a further notice of your wants and worth; and since you haue ingeniously discouer'd both your free education, present state, and vnauoydable affection to Astronomia, and, as you say, hers mutually to you, I shall, I trust, effectually, in your behalfe, remooue the vnwillingnesse of her Mother Physica. But withall, I hold it a course, not altogether without Policy, to inquire of Astronomia, the dislikes, for which she does except against you, and therein by a praeuenient discretion, exactly to manifest a reformation; for this time the expectation of some businesse admits not a further continuance of our discourse.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I shall rest, Sir, at the bountie of your vertue.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: A Gentleman of parts worth the taking notice of; well, such wits must bee nourisht: 'tis the saying of my Tacitus: Ingenia, studique oppresseris faciliùs quàm reuocaueris; & I remember he there shewes an analogie between mens wits and their bodies: They are (saith hee) both of them long a making, but soone marr'd. And indeed, young wittes that are worth the nourishing, when they see themselues neglected, are too-too prone to fall to desperate resolutions, arguing thus with themselues, That if Vertue and Learning cannot aduance them; by a reason from the contrary, neither Vice nor Ignorance can debase them; thus from bad premises drawing a worse conclusion, they ouerthrow in a moment the workmanship of many yeeres. But my Kins-woman Historia sayd she would be here by this. Oh, here she comes.
NOw Cousin, what? alwayes sad? alwayes sad?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Doe you admire at my sadnesse, when you know, nay when you are the cause of it?

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: I? Cousin? how? how?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p:
Your continuall declamations, Sir, against my most
lou'd Poeta, a man whose praises admit no Hyperbole; no, they transcend all; and whose worth we may admire rather then expresse.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Why Cousin? my declamations ha' beene onely against his faults, not his person, and so farre—

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Nay, for your State-distinctions you may reserue them to your selfe, you can loue and hate the same man at the same time by a distinction; I doe but plainely relate the truth vnto you, and I thinke there is hardly any man could more violently haue inueigh'd against him then your selfe; excepting old froward Ethicus; his age indeed must alwaies be correcting some body.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Why, but why should you regard him, when it seemes he little regards you?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Marry, and little reason he hath, when he sees the best of my friends, your selfe, and Ethicus to neglect him. But otherwise I'me sure he did loue me once: there haue bin of the Historias that haue beene well belou'd by Poets, and those the most renowned in all ages: as by admired Homer, the greatest glory and Shame of Greece, the one for his worth, the other for his wants: then by diuine Maro, that beautifull wonder of Nature; and especially by one Lucan, a worthy Gentleman of Rome, besides many more; that if you would vouchsafe but to grace him, his Lawrel would be the crowne of your glory.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: I but he beares loue to Astronomia.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p:
I vnderstand so much: but I think that rather the exiliency of some passion, then any consistency of a settled desire. I haue indeede heard also of some of the Astronomias that haue beene belou'd by Poets; as by Manilius, Pontanus, and some other, who haue written whole Bookes in the praise of their beauties; but it seemes their beauties had such small diuinity in them, that they could not raise, to any height of poeticke rapture, the wits of their admirers. And there was also one Lucretius, a Romane Gentleman, in former times that fell in loue with Physica, shee from whom Physica the mother of Astronomia deriues now both her name and linage, which Gentleman, in the passion of his loue, writ books in the praise
of her beauty; but what wrinkle-fac'd Verses they are, let the present age iudge; and if her beautie was like his lines, sure she was past her Three-score, when hee fell in loue with her; but alas, there was neuer any of that family that euer came neere the Historias for beauty.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Well, Cousin, then what is the imployment wherewith you will taske me?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Why, if you meane to haue mee aliue long, change your dislike of Poeta into loue, and reforme him if you will, but not hate him; admonish him, intreat him, woo him, and in a word, winne him vnto mee; and those hymnes of your praises, and relations of your glory shall bee put in the mouth of posteritie; that sooner shall the Common-wealth dye, then your fame.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Well, Cousin, you haue now enough admonisht me, entreated me, woo'd mee, and in a word wonne me: referre the finding out of meanes, and the accomplishing of your desire to the priuacie of my meditations.

sp.speaker: Histor.
sp.p: Reuerend Polites, pardon the vnmannerlinesse of my disordered passions; loue resisted growes rude and furious: but I will not instruct your wisedome; onely remember my life lies in your hands.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: And that shall not perish if I can saue it. There are many accusations in against this Poeta, and some of them I perceiue will be prosecuted; he has bad, and good parts; he has a wilde head, yet may be reform'd, and then there's a man sau'd: a good purchase; nay, Historia is sau'd, that's a double. Well, then since I must loue him, I will saue him: if hee proue good, I winne two; if bad, 'twill bee but the losse of one, of Historia; who already professes, that, without him, she shall be lost.

div.head: ACTVS IIII. SCENA III.
ASTRONOMIA, ASTROLOGIA, ARITHMETICA, POETA, MEDICVS, MVSICA.

sp.p: OH, I'me so hot, I could drinke a whole Riuer of water.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p:
Nay, if you talke of drinking, I could drinke my
selfe halfe a doozen Helicons off at a draught: Musica, fetch a flaggon of Wine.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Nay, let it be pure Water.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Haue a care what you doe: 'tis as much as your life's worth.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By Ioue wee will haue our liquor about vs. Goe Wench, why, Sir, should not she drinke?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Why, to drink in the heat of an Ague is present death; and I remember Galen in his Booke de consuetudine, relates a Storie of Arius a Peripateticke, who dyed suddenly, being forc'd to drinke a full draught of colde water in the heat of his Feuer; though according to the prescriptions of his Physicians: yet, I confesse, in him there was another adioyn'd cause, which Galen in the same place makes mention of, to wit, his stomake being alwayes very colde, hee resolu'd on a perpetuall abstinence from all colde nourishments, so that this aduentitious colde of the water hee dranke, wrought not onely against his disease, but also against his constitution.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Oh that was it, that was it; then fill out the liquor.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: You Poets would make mad Physicians; or at the best but desperate Paracelsians; But Astronomia, you stirre too much; and so the heate of your disease increases to an inflammation: you must rest more, you must rest more.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Nay, I shall neuer liue, if I leaue mouing.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I, but not so fast; you walke as fast as you do when you are in health.

sp.speaker: Astrol.
sp.p: Indeed, mee thinkes, shee keepes alwayes the same pace.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: I, but if you marke it, 'tis not a direct Progression, but a kind of giddie turning Round, which proceeds from a lightnesse of the head, caus'd by her disease.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I dislike your dyet; for in the verie hottest of Summer, when the Sunne is in Cancer, you eate the hottest meate, feeding altogether vpon Crab; which two concurrent heates of the Meat and of the Weather, are able to cast any man into the inflammation of a Feuer.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Indeed, I confesse that; and 'tis at that season, my only dyet.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I, but 'tis bad; and againe 'tis very good to feed vpon varietie of meate.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Say you so! marry, I thinke, you'l prooue a paradoxicall Paracelsian your selfe; if you hold such Tenents: for you know, Sir, 'tis the most receiued opinion of Physicians, that varietie of meates disturbes concoction.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sir, I hold that opinion rather to argue the Authors superstition, then iudgement: for our nature delighteth in varietie, and those meats which the stomake doth with pleasure desire, it doth most embracingly attract, and concoct most faithfully, besides the substance of our bodies consisting of a various nature, as moysture, ayre, and the like, one of these parts may be more spent then another, by labour, or other meanes; so that a man had need, for the vndoubted supply of all these parts, receiue a great varietie of nourishments, that there may be a reparation for whatsoeuer the bodie does euacuate.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I vnderstand Sir.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Besides, Astronomia, going abroad you neuer take care in what Ayre you walke.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Indeed, I confesse, I am too neglectiue of that.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Oh, that's a chiefe matter to bee prouided for; for the verie same ayre sometimes is hurtfull for one part of the bodie, and good for another.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: How? is that possible?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis a truth obseru'd by Guido Cauliacensis; and in particular of the ayre of Paris; where, if the same man haue a wound in his head, and another in his thigh; it hurts the one and heales the other.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: That's prettie i'faith: the reason, the reason, Master Physician.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p:
'Tis thus, Sir, the ayre there is cold and moyst, and therefore most hurtfull for the head; and againe, the same ayre by an obscuration of the spirits, a degrauation of the bloud, and a condensation of the humours, whereby they are made lesse quicke to flow downe, does therefore make the wounds of the thighes more curable, whiles the course of the humours is intercepted, whose defluence or flowing downe
would hinder the cure of the wound.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: You Physicians, I perceiue, sometimes haue some of Apollo in you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Pray, Medicus, tell me one thing; you'r a Physician; I haue heard Geographus relate of a place in his Trauels, where the people are heal'd by Musicke: is that possible?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O yes: Ile confirme it by mine owne experience: I knew a young Gentle man that marri'd a young Gentlewoman; who being extraordinarily faire, and he as melancholy, grew into a great iealousie, that shee had made him a Cuckold, vpon which conceit, at the first but light, the strength of his melancholy and iealousie working together; he fell into a strong perswasion that he had Hornes: the best Physicians were sent for, vs'd all medicines and inuentions to cure him, nothing preuail'd, whereupon they left him, intreating his wife to be patient, and expect his recouerie in time. Away they went, and none but a little boy was left in the roome to tend the Gentleman, when vpon a suddaine there comes mee by, a Bag-pipe-player, at the sound of whose Pipe the Gentleman suddainely arose, leapes about the Chamber, beates his head against the wall, so long, till at last he had broke his face in diuers places that the bloud gushed out; vpon the effusion of which melancholy bloud, that had corrupted his braine and phantasie, the Gentlemans Hornes were beaten off against the wall, and the Gentlewoman became as honest a woman after that time, as any in Europe.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: In good faith, you Physicians are the onely fellowes in the world to tell Tales by Gentlewomens Bed-sides, whiles they are sicke.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I, this Cure was by the effusion of bloud, but they whom Geographus tolde of, were healed without any such meanes.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p:
Ile satisfie you in that by another particularitie of experience: I knew another Gentleman, who being very sicke of a contagious disease, and finding no remedie by Medicine, the Physicians caus'd Musicians to bee brought into the roome, and play; at the hearing of which Musicke, hee suddainely leapes and continu'd dancing so long, till the laborious
exagitation of his whole bodie, had by sweat and breathing dissipated the contagion.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I wonder you Physicians doe not turne Trauailors, you'd haue an aduantage beyond them all, by making good your Relations, by giuing a reason for them.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O by no meanes, Sir; for if wee should trauaile into forraine Lands, our skill would there faile vs; by reason of the difference of the Countrie, and our ignorance of their constitutions and dyet.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Musica, some drinke; mee thinkes, I haue not one iot of moysture in me.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Musica, fetch none, shee shall drinke no more.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: I must drinke, the World was not in such a combustion at Phaeton's driuing the Chariot of the Sunne, as I am in now.

sp.speaker: Astrol.
sp.p: Come, come, Medicus, the strictnesse of your prescriptions must be dispenc'd with, a little.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Will you spoile her, Astrologia?

sp.speaker: Astrol.
sp.p: Ile warrant you, shee'l neuer dye of this disease, I haue calculated her Natiuitie, to know so much beyond your Art: the sixt House of her Horoscope, wherein all her diseases are Prefiguratiuely registred, promises a better issue of her sicknesse then so: besides, shee shall haue an happie Wombe, for I find in her Horoscope, Venus in her Exaltation, to wit, in Pisces, and Iupiter in the fift House, the Radiation of Venus falling on the First House, and of Iupiter on the Eleuenth, Luna being in the Seuenth, illustrating the Fift House with a Sextile Radiation; shee shall haue a beautifull Daughter, her name shall be Optica: there shall appeare at her Birth foure Sunnes, and as many Rain-bowes, and the Ayre ouer-against these Rain-bowes, shall seeme to bee full of Looking-glasses, and in the middle of each Raine-bow shall appeare a Peacockes taile, which being reflected from the Looking-glasses, shall proiect an infinitie of colours in the Ayre.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Astronomia, you goe too much, you'l neuer leaue your Walking, and if Copernicus were aliue againe, 'ifaith hee'd make you stand still.

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Some drinke. She drinkes and fals.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Helpe, Astronomia fals.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Marie, Heauens forbid.

sp.speaker: Medic.
sp.p: I, here's your drinke.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ah, Astrologia, you made no Reckoning of this sicknesse, I shall scarce e're trust you againe, as long as I know you: Come, let's haue her in, let's haue her in. Exeunt omnes.

NOw my sweet Deuils, I am euen sicke with expecting when Medicus will come and visit me: I feare, his physicke cannot worke vpon Poeta: that rogues Verses, I thinke, are a counter-charme against all our coniurations: a rope on his sixe-footed lowsie Hexameters: sure, the slaues skin is inchanted; the quilting of Aiax shield was but a thin Cheu'rill to it.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Why, but doe you thinke 'tis impenetrable?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Oh, farre tougher then a Tanners: I haue heard of a Poet, that hauing beene buried a matter of two or three hundred yeeres, has beene taken vp againe whole, without the least perishing of his skinne, as faire as any Vellome.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Nay, by this Hand, I hold them to be euerlasting villaines.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: And I know by his lookes, if he once settle his affection vpon a wench, hee'll pursue her more swiftly then euer Apollo did Daphne; for hee'll ouertake her before her Metamorphosis.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I, and I know the rascall to haue a soft and moist Hand, by which I also infallibly know hee loues: for take a Poet without his wine & his wench; and if he make not drie, pitifull drie Verses, Ile forsweare Fortune-telling as long as I liue.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: But, I hope, that wench shall not be Astronomia.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Ne'r feare that: I haue seriously obseru'd (taking an oportunitie the other day to looke on her) the whole composure of her Face; and first for her beautie, I must confesse it absolute; for there are the two causes of all beautie; a most exquisite Symmetrie, or correspondent commensuration of the parts; and an exact mixture of colours, which addes vnto the proportion an incomprehensible pulchritude: since which time, I haue taken a like view of Geographus and Geometres; now for their heights, Geographus is somewhat lower then shee; but Geometres is of her pitch iust; for the lines of proportion in their faces, I must confesse, I can hardly iudge which is most like her, well, I hope yet 'twill be Geometres, or if Geographus doe win her, 'twill be by his comely deportment: 'faith I wish him well, but wee must worke for them that feele vs in the fist.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Well, Rauens, croke here, and whosoe'r comes by, make a prey of him; in the meane time Ile to Astrologia, for I know not what's the reason on't, but my Spirits cannot informe me of any thing shee does, so that I must of necessitie to Astrologia, to know how things proceed: but there's one Galilaus an exquisite Mathematicean, an Italian: whom I came very lately acquainted with, by admirable lucke; and he has promis'd to helpe me to a glasse, by which I shall see all things as perfectly represented in Astronomia's house, as if I were there: till which time I must take the paines to haue it by relation; but to your charge, to your charge; croke Rauens, croke.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: HEre comes some body, Physiognomus; set a good Face on't and Affront him; and Ile set my Fingers a worke, presently.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Hold thy Hands there, 'tis Sanguis, hee's of our side, stay a little.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p:
Well, I shrowdly suspect my Master for this physicke:
but mum, I am o're-heard, I feare.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: How now, Sanguis? why doest thou blush so?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Doe I blush?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I'me sure thou look'st as red as fire; I thinke all the Bloud in thy body is in thy face.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Well, well, all your words will not make me a jot redder then I am: but, if you talke of blushing, I thinke you haue more need to blush, if you knew the report that goes of you.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Of vs?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: I, of you; but especially of Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Of me? what?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you are a Cut-purse.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I defie mine accusers, and I call honestie it selfe to witnesse, that I get my liuing by my fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come, come, leaue these protestations: a bad cause is better defended by silence, then argument.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Faith 'tis true; let vs be friends: and since thy Master Medicus has taught thee to Kill, wee'll teach thee to Steale: but honestly, Sanguis, honestly.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: We three will set vpon the next man we meet.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: I would 'twere Choler that broke my head t'other day: o' that condition, I'd stay; but my Master has sent me to Magus. I must begone.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Nay, stay a little longer now, Sanguis: who comes yonder? doe you know his Face?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Well, you wo will helpe me?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: My Hand shal be alwaies readie to help my friend.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Choler giues Sanguis a boxe on the eare, and they fall to cuffes .Choler, I'me Sanguis, and here's my head.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Sanguis, I'm Choler and here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: How? three against one? Hercules himselfe could not fight with such disaduantage: there's no ingenuitie in this; Ile take his part for pittie-sake at auenture, be it right or wrong. He helps Choler

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: O my nose, my nose—

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Ile make you too Sanguis crie your Bloodie nose before I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O my hand! my hand! O you rogue, you bow it quite double almost.
sp.stage: Enter MVSICA with a packe and a bottle of drinke.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why men, beasts, furies, what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Choler, Choler, draw thy knife, and flit Physiognomus his nose.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Ah you dull rogue, doe you kicke?
sp.stage: Enter PHLEGMATICO with a pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Oh, Phlegmatico! thou'rt welcome; but prethee throw away thy pipe; vnlesse 'twere one could make them dance after it, and so coole their furie.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Why, ho!

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Orpheus, they say, by musike held beasts by the eares; let Musica then hold the beastly furies of you, that are now by the eares.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Why, ho! They leaue fighting.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: He has pickt my pocket. Sirrah, Cheiromantes, you rogue, where's my hand-kercher?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Nay, giue him his hand-kercher, I saw you take it: there, there is thy hand-kercher, Melancholico: why I thought thou hadst beene no fighter.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: 'Faith, ingenuitie made me fight, when I saw three vpon one.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Come, come, for shame, be friends; you shall all be friends before you part.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Nay, I'm angrie with no body: I did but fight, to make them leaue fighting.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Nor we; for the quarrell was not ours.

sp.speaker: Cheir.
sp.p: Nor we; for the quarrell was not ours.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I thought 'twas Choler, and Sanguis, they still are prouoking one another: What hast thou in thy bottle, Musica? Nepenthe to reconcile the Gods?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: 'Faith here's drinke to reconcile these furies, if they will?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Come, Musica, doe you beginne, and wee'll all dance after thy pipe.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p:
You haue spoke truer then you thinke, for there is a Piper comming after me, and somebody else; they'll be here
anon: well, here's to you all then. Shee drinks. Hee drinks.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Phlegmatico, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Sanguis, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Choler, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Cheiromantes, haue at you.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Worke. (Choler drinks) Physiognomus, will you taste this liquor?

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Play off: (Cheiromantes drinks) Well then, I am last, Ile drinke to you all; Ile leaue ne'r a jot: (Hee drinks) there, Musica, there's thy bottle.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Sanguis and Choler shake hands; are you friends?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Cheiromantes, they say, you can tell fortunes; is it true?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Trie me.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Let's know all our fortunes then.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Come on, let me see your hand, sweet Musica: you shall be belou'd of two, a Courtier and a Scholer; you shall loue the Courtier more; but the Scholer shall haue you; and it shall so come to passe, that the Courtier shall afterward be your seruant: your husband shall be exceeding melancholy: you shall haue three sonnes; the first shall be call'd by his fathers name (but I know not what that shall be) and hee shall be extreme discontent and solitarie; and if he preuent a consumption, he may liue till fortie; for longer he cannot, being of a cold and drie constitution: the second shall be called Timido, and hee'll be indanger of being bit with a mad dogge; which if he scape, he may liue till fiftie: the third shall be called Iucundo; the other two tooke after their father; but hee'll take after his mother; hee will be exceedingly giuen to good cheere, musike, and women: he will be in danger of a Surfet; and of Fire; and if he scape these two, especially burning, he may liue to be an old man.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Tell me mine next.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: You, Phlegmatico; 'twill be long ere you can get you a wife; yet you'll haue one, and one daughter; the child will die very young, of the blacke Iaundice, and your wife of the dropsie.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Sirrah, I saw you steale before, and now I heare you lie, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Tell me mine next.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Ile tell you yours in your eare. He whispers in Melancholico's eare.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Thanks, deare Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nay, and fortunes be so good that are told in ones eare; Ile haue mine told in my care too.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Thus 'tis then. He whispers in his eare.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Pish, this is no such fine fortune.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Tell me mine openly.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Why, this 'tis: You, Choler, shall be somewhat happy in your wife: her name shall be Poenitentia; you shall haue two children; and one shall take only after you, his name shall be Furioso. He shal die in his young age, in an Ale-house, of a stab in at the mouth, which shal passe thorow his tongue, and braines. The other child shall be a daughter; shee shall take after her mother; her name shall be Lacryma, a modest sober girle, and one that shall be well beloued by wise men.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, this is a prettie mixt fortune; now, what's thine owne fortune and thy fellowes?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Oh, starke naught, starke naught; Ile conceale them.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Then fare you well; I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: 'Faith you shan't goe yet; what haue you in your packe?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Prethee, Musica, tell mee, what thou hast in thy packe?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, because you speake kindly now, and intreat me, Ile shew you.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Hay, braue! what's here?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Morrice-bels?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: And waste-coates, and napkins?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Why, how cam'st thou by them?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p:
Why, thus: my Mistris had beene ill a good while, and because I tended her very carefully; shee gaue mee leaue to recreate my selfe to day; and i'faith I light on merry companie, where they vs'd these jinglers: and when they had
done, they pray'd mee to carrie them home with this bottle of drinke.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Faith, and there were enow, wee'd dance.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Enow? now I thinke on't, there's iust enow, there's sixe paire.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Faith wee'll to it then, but what wouldst thou doe, Musica?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, Ile play the maid Marian.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: A match, a match: dresse, dresse, wee'll haue braue jingling. They dresse themselves.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I can't dance.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Nay, prethee be not sullen, good Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: If I doe, Ile weare no bels.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why then lay one paire aside.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: But I woun't dance now.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I woun't dance, vnlesse I haue one of the wrought waste-coates.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, now they haue put them on.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I care not, I woun't dance else.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Come prethee, Cheiromantes, slip off thine againe and change with him; Melancholico must haue his sullen humours. So, now we want nothing but the Tabor wee talk't of: but 'tis no matter, since he does not come, wee'll sing, and so make musike to our selues. Who can tune the Morrice best?
sp.stage: Enter an hobby horse dancing the Morrice and a Tabourer.
sp.p: Oh, The hobby horse rushes on them, and throwes them all downe .here they are both, here they are both.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O my arme, my arme!

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: O my shinne!

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Ah, murren on him; who the deuill's this?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I haue hurt my brest.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: O the side of my face!

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: A rope on you, must you throw me quite downe?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Prethee dance the morrice quietly with vs: vp, vp, ho, and wee'll dance. They dance three times, the hobby-horse ouer throwes them all againe, kisses Musica, and runnes away with the Tabourer.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: A murren goe with you— Musica, who play'd in the hobby-horse?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: No, I must not tell.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come then, wee'l goe now to Barly-breake.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I but there's one odde: what shall he doe? sit out euery time?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Yes faith, and giue a reason of the other three couples meeting.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Agreed: runne.
sp.stage:
They run and meet thus:
Sanguis.
Musica.
Physiognomus.
Cheiromantes.
Melancholico.
Phlegmatico.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: A murren on't, must I be the first man must sit out? nothing angers me but that.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Nay Choler, thou't fret and chafe now—

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come Choler, your reasons.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Why, thou and Musica are met together— because— Sanguine folkes are most fit for Musicke and sports. Physiognomus and Chieromantes met, because they fear'd wee would haue suspected they would haue pickt our pockets, if they had ioynd with any of vs—

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: We thanke you Choler, wee shall be euen with you, and't come to our turne.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Melancholico, and Phlegmatico ioyn'd; because one's too dry; and the other's too moist: and so they'l serue for Medicines one for another: come runne againe: Ile be sure to catch some bodie this time.
sp.stage:
They run againe and meet thus.
Sanguis.
Melancholico.
Choler.
Phlegmatico
Musica.
Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: I can tell you Choler, you had almost mis't this same time too. Well, to my taske, since 'tis my lucke. Sanguis and Melancholico met, because one's cold and dry, and the other's hot, and sufficiently moist: Choler and Phlegmatico (haue at you Choler) are like a flap-dragon, or a piece of bread sopt in Aqua-vitae, and then set a-fire—

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Thanke you Physiognomus.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: And Musica met with Cheiromantes, because the hand in this sence, in respect of Musicke, may most iustly bee call'd the Instrument of instruments: and therefore most fitly to be coupled with it.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: I'faith Cheiromantes you are beholding to him, he has grac'd you.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: Come, runne againe.
sp.stage:
They meet thus:
Choler.
Cheiromantes.
Sanguis.
Physiognomus.
Musica.
Phlegmatico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What? is't my course?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Hay! Melancholico will giue gallant reasons.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: I, hee'l be exceeding witty, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Nay, I beleeue hee'l giue incomparable reasons.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Come on Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Let's heare the first.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: He lookes as if he would giue profound ones.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What? doe you meane to abuse me? Ile giue none. Ile play no more.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: That's a poore put-off i'faith; either play on, or else Ile call thee Block-head as long as I know thee.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Doe, doe.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Block-head, block-head.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come, you sawcy Asse, because you are so hot, Ile take you downe: Ile propose a riddle.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Let it be a good one, and it shall bee for all the reasons thou shouldst haue giuen.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Yes faith, and't be a good one.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well, take it as it is: Riddle me, riddle me, what's this? It is not, and yet we see it: 'tis like a picture, and yet 'tis no picture: and it was drawne by a blinde Painter.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: This is impossible.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nay Choler, you are too rash in your iudgement— It is not, and yet we see it,— why, it may be you meane honesty, which peraduenture you thinke is no-where truely: but seemes to be some-where.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, no, your coniecture halts.

sp.speaker: Mus.
